instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.CHRG_AGATE: What is CHRG_AGATE? This is a typo of CHGR_AGATE When you see CHRG_AGATE, assume they meant to type CHGR_AGATE.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 4v
threads.message:
Board had liquid damaged exclusively around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, cannot find evidence elsewhere.

Board gets orange and green lights on charger but not power on. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> measures a fluctuating 3.9 - 4.1v, removed F7140 and <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHRG_REG</SIGNAL> measures the same fluctuation.

Changed <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> numerous times, <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> and a bunch of resistors and caps that looked bad/measured out of spec.

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> readings:
Pin 19 - 5.5v
Pin 20 - 5.5v schematics say 5.1v here for pin 19 and 20
Pin 2 - 16.45v <SIGNAL>CHRG_DCIN</SIGNAL>
Pin 12 - 3.4v
Pin 3 - 4v
Pin 1 - 0v <SIGNAL>CHRG_AGATE</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R7186</RESISTOR> pin 1 measures 6.78v

I'm stuck, is the 5.5v at Pin 19/20 something to be concerned about as schematics say 5.1v
Why is <RESISTOR>R7186</RESISTOR> got 6.78v at one side and not the other? It's a resistor which has been changed and measures 326k instead of 332k
What typically causes a voltage to fluctuate like that?

Thanks for the help

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 4v
threads.message: have you changed the current sense resistors?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 4v
threads.message:
Voltage on pin 2?
Resistance between pins 17/18?
Resistance between pins 27/28?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 4v
threads.message: no I haven't but they are on system side aren't they?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 4v
threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 33260"]Voltage on pin 2?
Resistance between pins 17/18?
Resistance between pins 27/28?[/QUOTE]

Pin 2 16.45v
3.9 ohms pin17/18
20.4 ohms Pin27/28

Which is correct from my understanding.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 4v
threads.message: ok found sense resistors for charger, checked charger BMON current sense <RESISTOR>R5429</RESISTOR> is 300k and <RESISTOR>R5439</RESISTOR> AMON sense is 45.3k both read 0v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 4v
threads.message: Remove F7140 to see if it is not the system pulling too much current.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 4v
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 33280"]Remove F7140 to see if it is not the system pulling too much current. [/QUOTE]

removed it sits at 4.8v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 4v
threads.message: Issue must be around <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> then. Voltage on <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 4v
threads.message: I figured the same and have stared at it and tested it for hours now.16.25v both sides

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 4v
threads.message: Bloody hell, just found <RESISTOR>R7125</RESISTOR> was missing, not even there. I can't believe I missed it.. Put one on and I have 12.57v at F7140 now. Put back and we have fan spin and a Apple logo
